fields.label_text:
British Galleries:
This cup was presented to Richard Godfrey, Member of Parliament for Romney, Kent, to acknowledge his service to that coastal town. Obelisks or steeples served to increase the height and grandeur of such cups. Romney's coat of arms is shown amongst waves, with dolphins, oysters and mussel shells.

fields.descriptive_line: Steeple cup, decorated with chased waves and dolphins. English (London), 1627 - 1628.
fields.physical_description:
Cup and cover made for presentation
[Cup] The foot is die-struck with an ovolo and flower repeat; it is engraved within a double chased line with an inscription. The foot is chased overall with waves, two dolphins and th head of a third, and with three mussels and two oyster shells. The stem consists of a a die-struck strip (a rose and oval repeat) below a cast shaped button. Above this a tuurned spindle supports a grooved hemispere, a second spindle and a larger chased hemispere to which the bases of three cast scrolls are attached. A pair of spindles support a cast button and socket, die-struck as on the lower stem; within the socket is a screw thread. The raised bowl rises from a plain disc and is chased overall with waves, four dolphins, six dolphin heads, five oysters and a mussel shell. Two equidistant circular plaques depict respectively a ship with the inscription 'SIGILLUM BARONUM DE ROMENEY' (the common seal of New Romney), three lions passant and 'SIGILLUM OFF'[ICIUM] MAIORATUS PORTUS DE ROMNEY' (the mayoralty seal of New Romney). Between them a vertical scroll is engraved 'Summa Cato, medium Cicero, dat Apicius imum'.
[cover (closure)] The cover rises from a plain verticle rim which fits inside the cup. The raised curved cover is chased with three dolphins, three dolphin heads and oyster and mussel shells. In the centre, above a plain disc, is an engraved disc with four crudely cast openwork scrolls. These scrolls support a pyramid to which a cast scroll is attached. The finial is a cast figure of a woman in classical dress holding a blank shield and an orb.
fields.dimensions: Height: 58.4 cm, Diameter: 15.6 cm, Diameter: 12.3 cm foot
fields.title: The ^Richard Godfrey Cup
fields.label:
British Galleries:
This cup was presented to Richard Godfrey, Member of Parliament for Romney, Kent, to acknowledge his service to that coastal town. Obelisks or steeples served to increase the height and grandeur of such cups. Romney's coat of arms is shown amongst waves, with dolphins, oysters and mussel shells. [27/03/2003]
fields.marks:
[Cup] 'Ricardus Godfreius Thome filius servitii sui ergo in tribus - issimis Parliamentiis a muncipio Romenensi hoc tantum xenium gratissime accepit I° Jan 1627'
[Cup] The common seal of New Romney: a circular motif with a ship in the centre and the insription 'SIGILLUM BARONUM DE ROMENEY' around the edge.
[Cup] The mayoralty seal of New Romney: a circular motif with three lions passant in the centre and the inscription 'SIGILLUM OFF'[ICUM] MAIORATUS PORTUS DE ROMNEY' around the edge.
[Cup] A scroll with an inscription 'Summa Cato, medium Cicero, dat Apicius imum'.
[Cup] F script in a beaded oval
[Cup] k in a shield  date letter
[Cup] lion passant  Sterling standard
[Cup] Leopard's head crowned
[Cup] lion passant  Sterling standard
fields.public_access_description:
Object Type
This standing cup and cover was made as a presentation cup and intended for display. It is known as a 'steeple' cup because of the pyramidal steeple on the cover. These steeples served to add height and thus increase the dramatic impact of the cup. In practical terms, however,  they also added a great deal of weight, making the cup unwieldy and  prone to damage. Steeple cups were made only in England.

Ownership & Use
The cup was commissioned by the Town Council of Romney, Kent, and presented to Richard Godfrey in recognition of his service to the town. The cup, cover and foot are richly decorated with dolphins, waves, mussels and oysters, marine motifs appropriate for one of England's Cinque Ports. These five ports remain part of an ancient jurisdiction originally set up as a defence against invaders along the southern coast of England. Obliged to assist the royal fleet, the towns received in return a great many privileges and became immensely wealthy. Two of the town's seals are depicted on the cup.
fields.bibliography: Glanville, Philippa. <u>Silver in Tudor and Early Stuart England, A Social History and Catalogue of the National Collection, 1480-1660</u>. London: Victoria and Albert Museum, 1990. pp.410-411.
fields.credit: Given by the Venerable D. Tait, Archdeacon of Rochester
fields.history_note:
Made for the Town Council of  Romney as a gift for Richard Godfrey, MP for Romney in the 1620s. Made in London by an unknown craftsman, signed 'F' in a beaded oval

The donor was the town of Romney, one of the Cinque Ports, whose commonalty and mayoral seals seals appear engraved in the plaques on the bowl; the recipient, Richard Godfrey, had close formal and family associations with Romney having served in three Parliaments as MP for the town (1623-4, 1625, 1626). Hence also the choice of dolphins. The town's right to the bearings in its seals had been reaffirmed by a heraldic visitation by Rouge Dragon in 1619. The Godfrey family had long associations with the Kent coastal towns, serving as jurats (burgesses) and as MPs; Thomas, Richard's father was one of the Earl of Northampton's clients and a member of his household. He sat as MP for Winchelsea in the Addled Parliament (1614).

Historical significance: While the quality of the silversmith's work is mediocre, there is considerable interest in the chasing, whose marine theme was clearly dictated by the nature of the commission.
